articles.headline: Trump Backers Battle Online Over Skilled Immigrants
articles.snippet: A fierce dispute erupted in the president-elect’s camp between immigration hard-liners and tech industry leaders including Elon Musk.
articles.abstract: A fierce dispute erupted in the president-elect’s camp between immigration hard-liners and tech industry leaders including Elon Musk.
articles.lead_paragraph: Weeks before President-elect Donald J. Trump is to take office, a major rift has emerged among his supporters over immigration and the place of foreign workers in the U.S. labor market.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac and Ken Bensinger

articles.headline: Putin Apologizes but Stops Short of Taking Responsibility for Kazakhstan Crash
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia told the Azerbaijani leader, Ilham Aliyev, in a phone call, “that the tragic incident took place in Russian airspace.”
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia told the Azerbaijani leader, Ilham Aliyev, in a phone call, “that the tragic incident took place in Russian airspace.”
articles.lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Saturday apologized for the crash of an Azerbaijan Airlines plane this past week, breaking the Kremlin’s three-day silence on the accident that killed 38 people. He did not explicitly acknowledge Russia’s responsibility for the crash.

articles.headline: Ignoring Warnings, a Growing Band of Tourists Venture to Afghanistan
articles.snippet: With the war now over, the Taliban are welcoming foreign travelers, even as governments advise their citizens to stay away.
articles.abstract: With the war now over, the Taliban are welcoming foreign travelers, even as governments advise their citizens to stay away.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yi-Pin Lin, an associate professor at Tufts University, proudly says he has vacationed in 120 nations over the past decade.
articles.byline: By David Zucchino and Elise Blanchard

articles.headline: Behind the Dismantling of Hezbollah: Decades of Israeli Intelligence
articles.snippet: A Times investigation shows how extensively Israel penetrated the Lebanese militia, closely tracking the group’s commanders and culminating in the assassination of its leader, Hassan Nasrallah.
articles.abstract: A Times investigation shows how extensively Israel penetrated the Lebanese militia, closely tracking the group’s commanders and culminating in the assassination of its leader, Hassan Nasrallah.
articles.lead_paragraph: Right up until he was assassinated, Hassan Nasrallah did not believe that Israel would kill him.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Sheera Frenkel and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: Anger and Agony in South Korea After Plane Crash-Lands, Killing 179
articles.snippet: A Jeju Air passenger jet carrying 181 people from Bangkok sped off the runway and burst into flames. Two crew were rescued in what was the country’s worst air disaster in decades.
articles.abstract: A Jeju Air passenger jet carrying 181 people from Bangkok sped off the runway and burst into flames. Two crew were rescued in what was the country’s worst air disaster in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: The passenger plane with 181 people onboard skidded on the runway at a high speed and slammed into a wall before exploding into flames.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun, John Yoon and Jin Yu Young

articles.headline: Charles Dolan, Cablevision Founder Who Sat Atop a Media Empire, Dies at 98
articles.snippet: His business choices were diverse and prolific: He founded HBO, bought Madison Square Garden and the New York Knicks, and took over a Long Island newspaper.
articles.abstract: His business choices were diverse and prolific: He founded HBO, bought Madison Square Garden and the New York Knicks, and took over a Long Island newspaper.
articles.lead_paragraph: Charles F. Dolan, who founded HBO, merged a group of small Long Island cable TV systems into a network he called Cablevision and amassed a fortune building an innovative communications, entertainment and sports empire that included Madison Square Garden and its professional teams, died on Saturday. He was 98.

articles.headline: In the Presidents’ Club, Carter Was the Odd Man Out
articles.snippet: Jimmy Carter’s relationship with his successors in the Oval Office, both Republicans and fellow Democrats, was generally tense because of his outspokenness. That never mattered to him.
articles.abstract: Jimmy Carter’s relationship with his successors in the Oval Office, both Republicans and fellow Democrats, was generally tense because of his outspokenness. That never mattered to him.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Biden stopped by former President Jimmy Carter’s home in Plains, Ga., in April 2021, it was more than just a show of respect from one commander in chief to another. It was the first time in the 40 years since Mr. Carter left the White House that any of his seven successors had visited him in his hometown.

articles.headline: Jimmy Carter Was Right About Materialism but, Alas, Wrong About Us
articles.snippet: “Too many of us now tend to worship self-indulgence and consumption,” he said in his 1979 “Crisis of Confidence” speech. If only we had listened.
articles.abstract: “Too many of us now tend to worship self-indulgence and consumption,” he said in his 1979 “Crisis of Confidence” speech. If only we had listened.
articles.lead_paragraph: Halfway into his presidency, Jimmy Carter’s back was against the wall. It was July 1979, the height of the energy crisis, and the beleaguered president went on national television to deliver not a speech, but a kind of sermon.

articles.headline: Social Media Companies Face Global Tug-of-War Over Free Speech
articles.snippet: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s picks for the F.C.C. and F.T.C. have vowed to remove censorship online. That conflicts with European regulators who are pushing for stricter moderation.
articles.abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s picks for the F.C.C. and F.T.C. have vowed to remove censorship online. That conflicts with European regulators who are pushing for stricter moderation.
articles.lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump and his allies have vowed to squash an online “censorship cartel” of social media firms that they say targets conservatives.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Adam Satariano

articles.headline: From Bird Strike to Crash: The Mystery of the Korean Plane’s Four Fateful Minutes
articles.snippet: The time between when the pilot reported a bird strike and when it crashed could be key to unraveling one of the world’s worst aviation disasters in years.
articles.abstract: The time between when the pilot reported a bird strike and when it crashed could be key to unraveling one of the world’s worst aviation disasters in years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Already 30 minutes behind schedule, the pilot flying the Jeju Air jet with 181 people on board was preparing to land at his destination in southwestern South Korea on Sunday morning when the control tower warned him about flocks of birds in the area.

articles.headline: Holding the ‘Title of Citizen,’ Carter Carved a New Mold for Ex-Presidents
articles.snippet: Jimmy Carter redefined what a president can do after departing the White House, leaving a lasting imprint through his work overseas, particularly in the realm of public health.
articles.abstract: Jimmy Carter redefined what a president can do after departing the White House, leaving a lasting imprint through his work overseas, particularly in the realm of public health.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Jimmy Carter had no idea what he was going to do next when he delivered his farewell address to the nation in January 1981. Defeated after a single term by Ronald Reagan, he simply told Americans that he would leave the White House and “take up once more the only title in our democracy superior to that of president — the title of citizen.”
